# Cambridge International ExaminationsCambridge International General Certificate of Secondary Education  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 214, 903, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 300, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/43October/November 20181 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is supplied with a small block of iron, a thermometer and an electrical heater of power \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 918, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A defibrillator is a machine that sends an electrical charge through the heart of a patient whose heart is not beating correctly. Doctors learn to use a defibrillator by practising on a medical dummy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 762, 136]]<|/det|>
Fig. 7.1 shows the two contacts of a defibrillator attached to a medical dummy.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 345, 531, 362]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 377, 919, 424]]<|/det|>
<pre>The contacts that touch the dummy are made from metal, and when the defibrillator is being used, one contact becomes strongly negatively charged and the other contact becomes strongly positively charged. The handles of the contacts are made from plastic, which is an electrical insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 759, 917, 791]]<|/det|>
Wire P has a diameter \(d\) and a length \(l\) . A second piece of wire Q is made of the same material as P.
